briefdescription.para: C99-like sized MIN/MAX constants for all integer types.

detaileddescription.para: For each n in the set 8, 16, 32, 64 we define wxINTn_MIN, wxINTn_MAX and wxUINTc_MAX (wxUINTc_MIN is always 0 and so is not defined).

briefdescription.para: Top level window styles common to wxFrame and wxDialog.
This macro will swap the bytes of the value variable from little endian to big endian or vice versa unconditionally, i.e.

detaileddescription.para: independently of the current platform.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: This macro will swap the bytes of the value variable from little endian to big endian or vice versa if the program is compiled on a big-endian architecture (such as Sun work stations).

detaileddescription.para: If the program has been compiled on a little-endian architecture, the value will be unchanged.
Use these macros to read data from and write data to a file that stores data in little-endian (for example Intel i386) format.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: This macro will swap the bytes of the value variable from little endian to big endian or vice versa if the program is compiled on a little-endian architecture (such as Intel PCs).

detaileddescription.para: If the program has been compiled on a big-endian architecture, the value will be unchanged.
Use these macros to read data from and write data to a file that stores data in big-endian format.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: This macro can be used in a class declaration to disable the generation of default assignment operator.

detaileddescription.para: Some classes have a well-defined copy constructor but cannot have an assignment operator, typically because they can't be modified once created. In such case, this macro can be used to disable the automatic assignment operator generation.

briefdescription.para: This macro can be used in a class declaration to disable the generation of default copy ctor and assignment operator.

detaileddescription.para: Some classes don't have a well-defined copying semantics. In this case the standard C++ convention is to not allow copying them. One way of achieving it is to use this macro which simply defines a private copy constructor and assignment operator.

Beware that simply not defining copy constructor and assignment operator is not enough as the compiler would provide its own automatically-generated versions of them -- hence the usefulness of this macro.
Notice that a semicolon must be used after this macro and that it changes the access specifier to private internally so it is better to use it at the end of the class declaration.

briefdescription.para: Analog of wxDECLARE_NO_COPY_CLASS() for template classes.

detaileddescription.para: This macro can be used for template classes (with a single template parameter) for the same purpose as wxDECLARE_NO_COPY_CLASS() is used with the non-template classes.

parameterdescription.para: The name of the template class.
The name of the template parameter.

briefdescription.para: Analog of wxDECLARE_NO_COPY_TEMPLATE_CLASS() for templates with 2 parameters.

detaileddescription.para: This macro can be used for template classes with two template parameters for the same purpose as wxDECLARE_NO_COPY_CLASS() is used with the non-template classes.

parameterdescription.para: The name of the template class.
The name of the first template parameter.
The name of the second template parameter.

briefdescription.para: This macro can be used around a function declaration to generate warnings indicating that this function is deprecated (i.e.

detaileddescription.para: obsolete and planned to be removed in the future) when it is used. Only Visual C++ 7 and higher and g++ compilers currently support this functionality.
Example of use:
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: This is a special version of wxDEPRECATED() macro which only does something when the deprecated function is used from the code outside wxWidgets itself but doesn't generate warnings when it is used from wxWidgets.

detaileddescription.para: It is used with the virtual functions which are called by the library itself -- even if such function is deprecated the library still has to call it to ensure that the existing code overriding it continues to work, but the use of this macro ensures that a deprecation warning will be generated if this function is used from the user code or, in case of Visual C++, even when it is simply overridden.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: This macro is similar to wxDEPRECATED() but can be used to not only declare the function function as deprecated but to also provide its (inline) implementation body.

detaileddescription.para: It can be used as following:
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: A helper macro allowing to easily define a simple deprecated accessor.

detaileddescription.para: Compared to wxDEPRECATED_INLINE() it saves a return statement and, especially, a strangely looking semicolon inside a macro.
This macro should be used for deprecated functions called by the library itself (usually for backwards compatibility reasons) and which are defined inline.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: wxEXPLICIT is a macro which expands to the C++ explicit keyword if the compiler supports it or nothing otherwise.

detaileddescription.para: Thus, it can be used even in the code which might have to be compiled with an old compiler without support for this language feature but still take advantage of it when it is available.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: GNU C++ compiler gives a warning for any class whose destructor is private unless it has a friend.

detaileddescription.para: This warning may sometimes be useful but it doesn't make sense for reference counted class which always delete themselves (hence destructor should be private) but don't necessarily have any friends, so this macro is provided to disable the warning in such case. The name parameter should be the name of the class but is only used to construct a unique friend class name internally.
Example of using the macro:
Notice that there should be no semicolon after this macro.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: A mask value to indicate both vertical and horizontal orientations.
A mask to extract direction from the combination of flags.
A value different from any valid alignment value.

detaileddescription.para: Note that you shouldn't use 0 for this as it's the value of (valid) alignments wxALIGN_LEFT and wxALIGN_TOP.

briefdescription.para: A mask to extract alignment from the combination of flags.

detaileddescription.para: Can be combined together.

briefdescription.para: This is different from wxBORDER_NONE as by default the controls do have a border.
Default background style value indicating that the background may be erased in the user-defined EVT_ERASE_BACKGROUND handler.

detaileddescription.para: If no such handler is defined (or if it skips the event), the effect of this style is the same as wxBG_STYLE_SYSTEM. If an empty handler (not skipping the event) is defined, the effect is the same as wxBG_STYLE_PAINT, i.e. the background is not erased at all until EVT_PAINT handler is executed.
This is the only background style value for which erase background events are generated at all.

briefdescription.para: Use the default background, as determined by the system or the current theme.

detaileddescription.para: If the window has been assigned a non-default background colour, it will be used for erasing its background. Otherwise the default background (which might be a gradient or a pattern) will be used.
EVT_ERASE_BACKGROUND event will not be generated at all for windows with this style.

briefdescription.para: Indicates that the background is only erased in the user-defined EVT_PAINT handler.

detaileddescription.para: Using this style avoids flicker which would result from redrawing the background twice if the EVT_PAINT handler entirely overwrites it. It must not be used however if the paint handler leaves any parts of the window unpainted as their contents is then undetermined. Only use it if you repaint the whole window in your handler.
EVT_ERASE_BACKGROUND event will not be generated at all for windows with this style.

briefdescription.para: Indicates that the window background is not erased, letting the parent window show through.

detaileddescription.para: Currently this style is only supported in wxOSX and wxGTK with compositing available, see wxWindow::IsTransparentBackgroundSupported().

briefdescription.para: This id delimits the lower bound of the range used by automatically-generated ids (i.e.

detaileddescription.para: those used when wxID_ANY is specified during construction).

briefdescription.para: This id delimits the upper bound of the range used by automatically-generated ids (i.e.

detaileddescription.para: those used when wxID_ANY is specified during construction).

briefdescription.para: No id matches this one when compared to it.
Id for a separator line in the menu (invalid for normal item).
Any id: means that we don't care about the id, whether when installing an event handler or when creating a new window.
IDs used by generic file dialog (13 consecutive starting from this value)
IDs used by generic file ctrl (4 consecutive starting from this value)

detaileddescription.para: Notice that some, but not all, of these IDs are also stock IDs, i.e. you can use them for the button or menu items without specifying the label which will be provided by the underlying platform itself. See the list of stock items" for the subset of standard IDs which are stock IDs as well.

briefdescription.para: Check (or toggle) tool button / menu item.
Normal tool button with a dropdown arrow next to it.

detaileddescription.para: Clicking the dropdown arrow sends a wxEVT_COMMAND_TOOL_DROPDOWN_CLICKED event and may also display the menu previously associated with the item with wxToolBar::SetDropdownMenu(). Currently this type of tools is supported under MSW and GTK.

briefdescription.para: Item kinds for use with wxMenu, wxMenuItem, and wxToolBar.
left or upper arrow to scroll by line
left or upper arrow to scroll by page
bar to the left/above the thumb
bar to the right/below the thumb
not in this window at all
Data format IDs used by wxDataFormat.

detaileddescription.para: This value is returned by wxKeyEvent::GetKeyCode() if there is no non-Unicode representation for the pressed key (e.g. a Cyrillic letter was entered when not using a Cyrillic locale) and by wxKeyEvent::GetUnicodeKey() if there is no Unicode representation for the key (this happens for the special, non printable, keys only, e.g. WXK_HOME).

simplesect.para: 2.9.2 (you can simply use 0 with previous versions).

detaileddescription.para: These are, by design, not compatible with Unicode characters. If you want to get a Unicode character from a key event, use wxKeyEvent::GetUnicodeKey() instead.

briefdescription.para: Note that under Mac OS X, to improve compatibility with other systems, 'WXK_CONTROL' represents the 'Command' key.

detaileddescription.para: Use this constant to work with keyboard shortcuts. See 'WXK_RAW_CONTROL' to get the state of the actual 'Control' key.

briefdescription.para: Under Mac OS X, where the 'Command' key is mapped to 'Control' to improve compatibility with other systems, WXK_RAW_CONTROL may be used to obtain the state of the actual 'Control' key ('WXK_CONTROL' would obtain the status of the 'Command' key).

detaileddescription.para: Under Windows/Linux/Others, this is equivalent to WXK_CONTROL

briefdescription.para: The following key codes are only generated under Windows currently.
This special key code was used to represent the key used for keyboard shortcuts.

detaileddescription.para: Under Mac OS X, this key maps to the 'Command' (aka logo or 'Apple') key, whereas on Linux/Windows/others this is the Control key, with the new semantic of WXK_CONTROL, WXK_COMMAND is not needed anymore

briefdescription.para: Virtual keycodes used by wxKeyEvent and some other wxWidgets functions.

detaileddescription.para: Note that the range 0..255 corresponds to the characters of the current locale, in particular the 32..127 subrange is for the ASCII symbols, and all the special key values such as WXK_END lie above this range.

briefdescription.para: Ctlr Key, corresponds to Command key on OS X.
used to describe the true Ctrl Key under OSX, identic to wxMOD_CONTROL on other platforms
deprecated, identic to wxMOD_CONTROL on all platforms
This enum contains bit mask constants used in wxKeyEvent.
Double Japanese Postcard Rotated 148 x 200 mm.
Paper size types for use with the printing framework.
Send postscript data into a stream.
Flags which can be used in wxWindow::UpdateWindowUI().
The type for screen and DC coordinates.
32 bit IEEE float ( 1 sign, 8 exponent bits, 23 fraction bits ).

detaileddescription.para: (The mapping is more complex than a simple typedef and is not shown here).

briefdescription.para: 64 bit IEEE float ( 1 sign, 11 exponent bits, 52 fraction bits ).

detaileddescription.para: (The mapping is more complex than a simple typedef and is not shown here).

briefdescription.para: Native fastest representation that has at least wxFloat64 precision, so use the IEEE types for storage, and this for calculations.

detaileddescription.para: (The mapping is more complex than a simple typedef and is not shown here).

briefdescription.para: A special value meaning "use default coordinate".
A function which deletes and nulls the pointer.

detaileddescription.para: This function uses operator delete to free the pointer and also sets it to NULL. Notice that this does not work for arrays, use wxDELETEA() for them.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: A function which deletes and nulls the pointer.

detaileddescription.para: This function uses vector operator delete (delete[]) to free the array pointer and also sets it to NULL. Notice that this does not work for non-array pointers, use wxDELETE() for them.
wxDELETE() Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>

briefdescription.para: Swaps the contents of two variables.

detaileddescription.para: This is similar to std::swap() but can be used even on the platforms where the standard C++ library is not available (if you don't target such platforms, please use std::swap() instead).
The function relies on type T being copy constructible and assignable.

briefdescription.para: This macro is the same as the standard C99 va_copy for the compilers which support it or its replacement for those that don't.

detaileddescription.para: It must be used to preserve the value of a va_list object if you need to use it after passing it to another function because it can be modified by the latter.
As with va_start, each call to wxVaCopy must have a matching va_end.
Include file: #include <wx/defs.h>
